video.title_en: The Brilliant Experiment That Changed The Way We See Light

summary.text_en: Ibn al-Haytham (known in the West as Alhazen) completed his magnum opus, 'Book of Optics' (Kitab al-Manazir), while under house arrest. He completely overthrew the ancient Greek (Ptolemy and Euclid) 'Emission Theory' of vision (that eyes shoot out light beams), proving through rigorous experimentation the 'Intromission Theory' (light reflects off objects into the eye). He detailed the anatomy of the eye and correctly explained the 'Camera Obscura' principle. Crucially, he systematically used the 'scientific method' to test hypotheses, earning him the title of the 'First True Scientist'.
key_points_en: Established 'Intromission Theory': light enters the eye
Known as the 'Father of Modern Optics'

story.text_en: Al-Haytham's story is dramatic. He boasted he could regulate the Nile's floods and was summoned by the Fatimid Caliph (the 'Mad Caliph' Al-Hakim). Upon realizing the task was impossible, Al-Haytham had to 'feign madness' to avoid execution. The Caliph placed him under house arrest in Cairo. During ten years of dark confinement, he observed light passing through a pinhole in his shutters, projecting an 'inverted image' of the outside world onto the wall. This epiphany convinced him that light travels in straight lines and vision is caused by external light entering the eye, not leaving it. In the darkness, he wrote the seven-volume 'Book of Optics' that changed physics forever.

fun_facts.text_en: The word 'Camera' comes from 'Camera Obscura' (Dark Room), which is a direct translation of the Arabic word 'Qamara' (dark/private room), the term Al-Haytham used for his optical experiments.
He was a psychologist as well as a physicist. He correctly identified that while the eye 'receives' the image, the act of 'seeing' (recognition) actually happens in the brain.

simple_explanation.text_en:
Before Al-Haytham, geniuses like Euclid and Ptolemy thought human eyes were like 'Superman'â€”shooting out invisible 'laser beams' to scan objects. Al-Haytham said, 'That makes no sense. If so, why can we see distant stars the instant we open our eyes? Where does the eye get that energy?'
He used a simple proof: Staring at the sun hurts. If the eye projects light, why would the sun hurt it?
He proved: The eye is not a 'flashlight', it is a 'camera'. Light reflects off objects, goes through the pupil (lens), and paints an image on the retina (film).

applications.text_en: He studied optical illusions (like the Moon Illusion), pioneering the study of the psychology of visual perception.

impact.text_en: 'Book of Optics' was translated into Latin (as *Opticae Thesaurus*) in the 12th century and had a profound impact on Europe. Roger Bacon, Da Vinci, Kepler, and Newton were all deeply influenced by it. Al-Haytham transformed optics from a 'branch of geometry' into an independent science based on 'physical experiment' and 'physiology'. He is universally recognized as the 'Father of Optics'.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Ptolemy (whose 'Optics' was the main work Al-Haytham critiqued and corrected)
Aristotle (provided the physical intuition that 'light is motion in a medium', opposing emission theory)

influenced.contribution_en: Kepler (he finished what Al-Haytham started, correctly explaining the inverted image on the retina)
Newton (whose experimental method in optics was steeped in the tradition of Al-Haytham)
Da Vinci (deeply studied Al-Haytham's camera obscura theory for painting and perspective)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Ibn al-Haytham taught the world: Do not trust the ancients; trust your own eyes (and experiments).

quiz.question_en: What ancient theory of vision did Ibn al-Haytham (Alhazen) disprove?
quiz.explanation_en: Before him, Euclid and Ptolemy believed the eye emitted 'visual rays' to sense objects (Emission Theory). Al-Haytham proved through experiment (e.g., pain from looking at the sun, the dark room) that light exists independently and vision is light *entering* the eye.
